facts.text: This appeal is by special leave against the orders dated September 27, 1966 of the Industrial Court Madhya Pradesh, Indore, in Revisions Nos. 46 and 5/MPIR/66.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is against the orders dated September 27, 1966 of the Industrial Court Madhya Pradesh, Indore, in Revisions Nos. 46 and 5/MPIR/66 reversing the order dated February 25, 1966 passed by the Presiding Officer, Labour Court, Ujjain, in case No. 17 of 1969 Labour.

facts.text: Industrial Court reversed the order dated February 25, 1966 passed by the Presiding Officer, Labour Court, Ujjain, in case No. 17 of 1969 Labour.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is against the orders dated September 27, 1966 of the Industrial Court Madhya Pradesh, Indore, in Revisions Nos. 46 and 5/MPIR/66 reversing the order dated February 25, 1966 passed by the Presiding Officer, Labour Court, Ujjain, in case No. 17 of 1969 Labour.

facts.text: Appellant was an employee of the respondent Company working in its Coal and Bardana section as Coal Ash Supervisor.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, at the material time, was an employee of the respondent Company and was working in its Coal and Bardana section as Coal Ash Supervisor. He was on duty on the morning of April 24, 1963.

facts.text: Appellant was on duty on the morning of April 24, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: He was on duty on the morning of April 24, 1963. It was the duty of the appellant to sign and issue slips to the companytractors in order to enable the latters to remove companyl ash on donkeys outside the premises of the Company.

facts.text: Duty of appellant was to sign and issue slips to company tractors to enable removal of company ash on donkeys outside premises.

anchor.surface_text: It was the duty of the appellant to sign and issue slips to the companytractors in order to enable the latters to remove companyl ash on donkeys outside the premises of the Company.

facts.text: Company suspected malpractice by appellant in issue of slips, suspended him and issued charge sheet dated April 26, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: As, according to the Company, some mal practice was suspected on the part of the appellant in the issue of such slips, the latter was suspended and a charge sheet dated April 26, 1963, issued.

facts.text: Charge-sheet stated appellant issued gate pass to Bhagirath on April 24, 1965 for 48 donkey loads of company ash.

anchor.surface_text: In the charge-sheet it was stated that the appellant had issued gate pass to one Bhagirath on April 24, 1965 in order to enable the latter to remove 48 donkey loads of companyl ash.

facts.text: Appellant gave eight more slips to Bhagirath on April 25, 1963 to remove additional material.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the appellant gave eight more slips to Bhagirath on April 25, 1963 to enable the latter to remove additional material from the Companys premises.

facts.text: Bhagirath was discovered removing extra goods at the gate which he was not entitled to.

anchor.surface_text: On checking at the gate, it was discovered that Bhagirath was removing extra goods which he was number entitled to do.

facts.text: Appellant charged under Standing Order No. 12 for dishonesty in connection with company's business/property.

anchor.surface_text: On these allegations, the appellant was charged under Standing Order No. 12 for dishonesty in companynection with the business of the Companys property.

facts.text: Appellant replied to charge sheet on April 29, 1963 denying dishonesty, pleaded rush of work and mistake.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant sent on April 29, 1963 a fairly elaborate answer to the show cause numberice. He companytroverted the allegations that he had acted dishonestly in dealing with the Companys property.

facts.text: Enquiry held, appellant discharged from service with effect from May 15, 1963, order dated May 3, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the inquiry, the appellant was discharged from service with effect from 15-5-63. ... the order proceeds to state ... discharged from service with effect from May 15, 1963

facts.text: Appellant sent Approach Notice dated July 26, 1963 to Company under proviso to Section 31(3) of MPIR Act 1960 requesting reconsideration and reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant sent a letter dated July 26, 1963 to the Company as required by the proviso to Section 31 3  of the Madhya Pradesh Industrial Relations Act, 1960 ... requesting the Company to reconsider its previous decision dated May 3, 1963 and reinstate him in service.

facts.text: Company replied declining to reconsider and take back appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Company sent a reply declining to reconsider its previous decision and informed the workman that he cannot be taken back into service.

facts.text: Appellant filed application before Labour Court Ujjain under Section 31(3) as Case No. 17 of 1963 Labour challenging discharge order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an application before the Presiding Officer, Labour Court, Ujjain under Section 31 3  of the Act, praying for setting aside the order dated May 3, 1963 ... registered as Case No. 17 of 1963 Labour.

facts.text: Appellant challenged inquiry as by unauthorised persons, not by Manager, refusal of documents, mala fide, victimisation for union activities.

anchor.surface_text: In his application the appellant challenged the order of the management on various grounds. He averred that the inquiry proceedings were companyducted against him by unauthorised persons ... victimised as he was taking part in the Unions activities.

facts.text: Company denied mala fide and victimisation, stated inquiry by competent persons, order by competent authority.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Company denied the allegation mala fide and victimisation. It was alleged that the inquiry proceedings have been companyducted in accordance with the Standing Orders of the Company by companypetent persons ...

facts.text: Labour Court found appellant permanent employee for about a year, no mala fides or victimisation.

anchor.surface_text: The findings recorded by the Labour Court ... The appellant was a permanent employee of the Company, though he had been in service only for about a year. ... number vitiated by mala fides, number was it prompted with a view to victimize the appellant ...

facts.text: Labour Court held enquiry proper by Abde Ali and Trivedi, authorised.

anchor.surface_text: ... the enquiry companyducted by Sri Abde Ali and Shri Trivedi was also proper, as the latter two officers had been given the power to companyduct inquiries.

facts.text: Labour Court held order of May 3, 1963 invalid as not passed by Manager.

anchor.surface_text: The order dated May, 3, 1963 has number been passed by the Manager and therefore it is number valid.

facts.text: Labour Court found appellant's plea of mistake in issuing slips not acceptable, misconduct established with suspicion on honesty.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the appellant that he had issued the extra slips to Bhagirath due to mistake or inadvertence cannot be accepted ... It is established that Bhagirath was given additional slips by the appellant ...

facts.text: Labour Court ordered company to pay 5 months salary plus 1 month in lieu of notice, no reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: ... the Labour Court ordered the Company to pay the workmen companycerned five months salary as also one months salary due to him in lieu of numberice.

facts.text: Company filed revision No. 46/MPIR/66, workman revision No. 50/MPIR/66 before Industrial Court under Sections 66 and 67.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Company filed revision petition No. 46/MPIR of 1966 ... The workman also filed revision No. 50/MPIR of 1966 ... under Section 66 and 67 of the Act.

facts.text: Industrial Court on September 27, 1966 accepted company's revision, dismissed workman's, held discharge order valid, enquiry without infirmity.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court by its order dated September 27, 1966 accepted the revision petition filed by the Company and held that the order dated May 3, 1963 is valid and that the domestic enquiry ...

facts.text: Industrial Court held order signed by Bhagrodia (principal officer) and Abde Ali (authorised).

anchor.surface_text: ... the order dated May 3, 1963 has been signed both by Bhagrodia, who was the principal officer of the Company ... as also by Abde Ali who had the authority to hold the enquiry.

facts.text: Supreme Court held enquiry conducted by competent officers Abde Ali and Trivedi authorised by Factory Manager Srivastava.

anchor.surface_text: ... the finding of the Labour Court and accepted by the Industrial Court is that both Abde Ali as well as Trivedi, who companyducted the enquiry were persons empowered to do so. The authority letter Ext. D39A clearly shows ...

facts.text: Appellant requested production of slips on May 2, 1963 after witnesses examined, request rejected.

anchor.surface_text: ... the appellant filed an application before the Enquiry Officer on May 2, 1963 requesting him to make available certain gate passes. ... this application was received after the said two witnesses had been examined on May 3, 1963.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no prejudice to appellant from non-production of slips, his plea afterthought.

anchor.surface_text: ... the finding of the Industrial Court that numberprejudice has been caused to the appellant is justified. The Labour Court itself has recorded a finding ...

facts.text: Labour Court found appellant attempted to induce Jodha Ram to destroy pages in Work Register.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant may have made a request to Jodha Ram for destroying three pages in the Work Register in order to escape punishment ...

facts.text: Supreme Court held Abde Ali and Bhagrodia competent to pass discharge order under Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: ... Abde Ali has been authorised by Shri Srivastava to companyduct all enquiries ... The Industrial Court has found that the order has been also signed by Bhagrodia, who was the Secretary ...

facts.text: Bhagrodia superior to Manager Srivastava, appointing/dismissing authority, authorised when Srivastava on leave.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagrodia has given evidence ... the Factory Manager Shri Srivastava was subordinate to him. ... whenever Shri Srivastava went out of station, he used to authorise him ... During the enquiry ... Shri Srivastava went on leave ...

This appeal, by special leave, is against the orders dated September 27, 1966 of the Industrial Court Madhya Pradesh, Indore, in Revisions Nos. 46 and 5/MPIR/66 reversing the order dated February 25, 1966 passed by the Presiding Officer, Labour Court, Ujjain, in case No. 17 of 1969 Labour.

The appellant sent a letter dated July 26, 1963 to the Company as required by the proviso to Section 31 3  of the Madhya Pradesh Industrial Relations Act, 1960 (Act No. 27 of 1960) hereinafter to be referred as the Act . This notice is called an Approach Notice and by that notice the appellant requested the Company to reconsider its previous decision dated May 3, 1963 and reinstate him in service.

holdings.text: The enquiry proceedings have been properly conducted by the officers, competent under the Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: the finding of the Labour Court and accepted by the Industrial Court is that both Abde Ali as well as Trivedi, who conducted the enquiry were persons empowered to do so. The authority letter Ext. D39A clearly shows

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of Labour Court and Industrial Court; Abde Ali and Trivedi authorised by Factory Manager Srivastava under Ext. D39A to conduct enquiries.

holdings.text: There is no violation of the principles of natural justice in the enquiry proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that the finding of the Industrial Court that there is no violation of the principles of natural justice is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prejudice caused to appellant as request for slips was belated after witnesses examined, an afterthought; Labour Court found plea unbelievable and evidence of guilty mind.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authorisation under Ext. D39A comprehensive, making him a 'Manager' per Clause 1(a); competent to issue punishment order.

holdings.text: The discharge order is valid as signed by superior authority Bhagrodia, who was authorised during Manager's leave.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bhagrodia superior to Srivastava, appointing/dismissing authority; specifically authorised during leave; unchallenged evidence.

holdings.text: The order of discharge has been passed by the competent officer.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the matter from any point of view, it follows that the view of the Industrial Court that the order of discharge has been passed by the competent officer is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: From any perspective: Abde Ali authorised; alternatively Bhagrodia higher authority or authorised substitute.

holdings.text: The Industrial Court has not exceeded its jurisdiction under Sections 66 and 67 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the last contention, we are not satisfied that the industrial Court has in any manner exceeded its jurisdiction under Section 66 and 67 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Justified in correcting serious errors and illegalities by Labour Court in its findings on validity of enquiry and order.
